children.subject:
Going off of http://catalog.mit.edu/subjects/6/, I count 58 courses listed under the "Basic Undergraduate Subjects" and "Undergraduate Laboratory Subjects" sections (excluding special topics courses (since I also excluded them from Berkeley's count) and courses only offered during MIT's special IAP term (which is only 4 weeks)).

There are also lots of courses under "Advanced Undergraduate Subjects and Graduate Subjects By Area", but I don't feel like comparing those vs our own listing of graduate courses.

Also, look at other universities. MIT offers far more CS courses. Also, they're on the semester system.

https://ocw.mit.edu/courses/electrical-engineering-and-computer-science/

My point is, Berkeley is just as good as MIT. If they can do it, so can we.

history.content:
I count 17 upper-division CS courses and 27 EE courses in the page you linked, a page that doesn't include any of the special topics courses. By my count, we also have 14 lower-division CS and 2 lower-division EE courses, for 60 courses in total.

As for grad courses, I count 5 CS grad courses that correspond to an undergrad course (by looking at which ones say "Can't get credit after taking X"): 249A, 260A, 284A, 286A, 289A. That leaves all of the other grad courses (including the B version of most of the above 5) to cover new material. The "Advanced Algorithms" and "Advanced AI" courses you seek can both be found among these grad classes. (If you want "Advanced Data Structures", just take any course that uses those specific data structures.

I count 17 upper-division CS courses and 27 EE courses in the page you linked, a page that doesn't include any of the special topics courses. By my count, we also have 14 lower-division CS and 2 lower-division EE courses, for 60 courses in total.

As for grad courses, I count 5 CS grad courses that correspond to an undergrad course (by looking at which ones say "Can't get credit after taking X"): 249A, 260A, 284A, 286A, 289A. That leaves all of the other grad courses (including the B version of most of the above 5) to cover new material. The "Advanced Algorithms" and "Advanced AI" courses you seek can both be found among these grad classes. (If you want "Advanced Data Structures", just take any course that uses those specific data structures.)

Below, you compare against MIT, which has a single combined EECS department (i.e. includes both EE + CS courses in that list), is also on the quarter system, and also includes intro courses. This is a list of 87 distinct courses.

If we loosely approximate a semester as 1.5 quarter courses (since that's how units convert), our 60 courses $$\approx$$ 90 quarter courses, which is actually higher than MIT's listing.

(I'm not taking into account differences in the typical workload of a Berkeley EECS course vs an MIT course, e.g. I didn't look at how many units each MIT course is worth and what a typical schedule there is.)

children.subject:
HKN isn't an official Berkeley website, and so I don't recommend using it to figure out what courses are offered.

Instead, try Berkeley's course listings:

http://guide.berkeley.edu/courses/compsci/

http://guide.berkeley.edu/courses/el_eng/
Steven, you're right about how many classes we have. However, many of them aren't offered anymore or are offered very infrequently. That is a problem as well

That's a staffing + funding issue, yes.

Compare to other departments at Berkeley:

In spring 2016, if we filter by "courses with at least 20 students", the average number of such courses in each L&S department was 7.4, with a median of 2.

The departments with the most such courses were PE (84 courses), Math (57), CS (56), English (42), Molecular & Cell Biology (38), History (38), Physics (38), Econ (36).

(Note that the discrepancy between here and the above post is the inclusion of special topics courses / decals / seminars / w/e. The filter of 20 students is to try and exclude some not-courses like research units and such; if you remove the filter, CS is still at 4th place, with 202 "courses".)

In some departments, even core courses (that are required for all students) are only taught once a semester.

Also consider that there's been enough issues in this department getting sufficient funding to hire TAs for the classes that are offered.

And not all professors are interested in teaching every course; that's why some classes get canceled (e.g. @2310).

It would certainly be nice to have more courses and more professors, but there are practical limitations on resources, and comparatively speaking, we're doing fairly well.

Oh, if there's a specific course you would like taught more frequently, I'm given to understand that your best bet is to find some professor and convince them to teach it (e.g. that there's enough interest in the course). That's the real bottleneck.
Steven Bi, how can I convince you to teach a course?

In some departments, even core courses (that are required for all students) are only taught once a semester.

All classes are taught at most once a semester.

Oops, meant once a year.

Also, something about not being able to teach.
+1 Steven Bi would be the greatest Professor I've ever had at Cal.
Not just at Cal, but in the history of the known universe.
Steven Bi: Where did  you find the list of grad courses? It's not on the hkn link lol.
Steven: Can you share a list of upper div CS/EE classes you've taken? Thanks!

history.content:
https://hkn.eecs.berkeley.edu/courseguides

There's only around 15 CS upper div's, of which half are offered each semester. Seriously, why don't they create and offer new courses? I personally would love to take Advanced Algorithms, Advanced AI, and Advanced Data Structures.

I understand you can take graduate courses, but many grad courses are just the undergrad courses with an extra project (CS 189/289). Also, not many grad courses are offered. I don't see what's stopping the CS department. Do they not have enough money to hire new professors? This would instantly fix the overcrowding problem.

Also, I know you can take non-CS classes like Cog Sci, Stats and Math. Many students want to learn more CS though instead. It should be an option.
history.subject: Why are there so few CS upper div's?

history.content:
https://hkn.eecs.berkeley.edu/courseguides

There's only around 15 CS upper div's, of which half are offered each semester. Seriously, why don't they create and offer new courses? I personally would love to take Advanced Algorithms, Advanced AI, and Advanced Data Structures.

I understand you can take graduate courses, but many grad courses are just the undergrad courses with an extra project (CS 189/289). I don't see what's stopping the CS department. The only explanation I can see is that they don't have enough money to hire extra professors. Still, the department would have to spend less on the overcrowded upper divs and have more money to spend.
history.subject: Why are there so few CS upper div's?
